request_pathways.name: Authorization to Disclose Protected Health Information (Jan 2025)

forms.document_type: ROI authorization form (DOCX variant, older revision)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a generic HIPAA disclosure authorization form, selects 'Personal Records' as the purpose, enters themselves as the 'TO' party, and submits via fax or in-person delivery.

red_flags: No electronic delivery options for records (only physical Pick Up or Send Out)
Multiple overlapping form versions published online with no guidance on which to use
Instruction 4 conditions processing on internal record completeness, which patients cannot control
bright_spots: Includes Reproductive Health Care and Gender Affirming Care record categories (Jan 2025 update)
Clear voluntariness statement: patients do not need to sign to receive health services
Verbal communication designee section for authorizing up to three contacts

findability.rationale: Level 4: Forms are easy to find with basic web searches returning direct PDF links; no login or bot blocking, though multiple unversioned forms and no dedicated landing page prevent a 5.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Form is a flat PDF (0 fillable fields) requiring print-and-handwrite, but fax submission is available as an electronic pathway; PDF annotation tools provide a workaround for digital completion.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Logical two-page structure with instructions and clear required-field marking, but dense page 2 layout, misaligned checkbox columns, ALL CAPS directives, and bureaucratic Instruction 4 create notable clarity problems.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: Generic disclosure form with a 'Personal Records' checkbox lets patients use the process, but the FROM/TO third-party paradigm and lack of dedicated patient access pathway mean patients must figure out which parts apply to self-access.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: No notarization, clear voluntariness and revocation statements, reasonable 12-month expiration; minor ambiguities in fee disclosure and the Instruction 4 processing condition, but nothing materially impeding patient rights.

overall.summary: Brattleboro Memorial Hospital provides easily findable forms with no egregious barriers, but the generic third-party disclosure workflow, non-fillable PDF format, and absence of electronic delivery options result in a functional but not patient-centered experience.
